standard: Land Use and Forestry - Afforestation and Reforestation

term_definitions.name: Tree
term_definitions.description: A tree is a perennial woody plant with one or several dominant sprouts that increase its circumference due to secondary growth. For a practical use of this document the definition of a tree in these requirements goes beyond the scientific definition of a tree and also includes shrubs, palms and bamboo plants. Differences in the context of specific requirements are noted on the individual pages. In any project, trees shall reach a minimum height of 2 meters. For forest inventories of these different types of trees, additional guidance is provided by the forest inventory guidelines in the BioCarbon Fund Sourcebook.

term_definitions.name: Forest
term_definitions.description: A forest is defined by the Designated National Authority (DNA) or equivalent entity of the project's host country. In case no forest definition is yet given by the DNA, the Project Developer can refer to the forest definition of the FAO or the national forest definition of the project's host country.

term_definitions.name: Wetland
term_definitions.description: Wetlands are lands that are transitional between terrestrial and aquatic systems where the water table is usually at or near the surface or the land is covered by shallow water, and that have one or more of these listed attributes.
attributes: At least periodically, the land supports predominantly hydrophytes.
The substrate is predominantly undrained hydric soil.
The substrate is non-soil and is saturated with water or covered by shallow water at some time during the growing season of each year.

term_definitions.name: Organic Soil
term_definitions.description: Organic soils fulfil at least one of these attributes.
attributes: If the soil is never saturated with water for more than a few days, and contains >20% (by weight) of organic carbon (35% organic matter).

If the soil is saturated with water for more than a few days at a time, and contains >12% (by weight) of organic carbon (20% organic matter) if no clay, or >18% (by weight) of organic carbon (30% organic matter) if it has >60% clay, or has a proportional lower limit of organic carbon content between 12 and 18% if the clay content of the minreal fraction is between 0 and 60%.

term_definitions.name: Selective Harvesting
term_definitions.description: Selective harvesting is done through the continuous harvest of single trees or groups of trees while maintaining forest on the area.

term_definitions.name: Planting
term_definitions.description: Planting refers to the activity of putting trees in the ground for growth; it also includes sowing or assisted natural regeneration.

term_definitions.name: Modelling Unit (MU)
term_definitions.description: Modelling Units are distinct parts of the planting area where carbon stocks can be quantified based on applying a forest growth-model. To meet the precision level for the carbon stocks estimation (see section CO2 removal), MU areas normally have homogeneous characteristics in their growth patterns, silvicultural treatment and planting date.

term_definitions.name: Significant
term_definitions.description: More than 5% of the 'long-term CO2 removal' - see section 'CO2 removal'.

term_definitions.name: Leakage
term_definitions.description: Emissions that occur due to a shift of activities from the inside of a project area to the outside of a project area.

term_definitions.name: Area
term_definitions.description: Land within the project area where the activity is taking place.

term_definitions.name: % activity shift
term_definitions.description: Percentage of the activity that will be displaced during the crediting period, and will have impact on the 'tree biomass' outside the project area. The factor is determined by a credible estimations, or a representative survey.

term_definitions.name: CO2 Stock
term_definitions.description: Average stock of 'tree biomass' on the area where the activity will be displaced to. If it is not known where the activity will be displaced to, the CO2-stock = the average stock of 'tree biomass' of a natural forest in the projects host-country.

term_definitions.name: Displaced Heads
term_definitions.description: Amount of heads that will be displaced during the crediting period, and will have impact on the 'tree biomass' outside the project area. The factor is determined by a credible estimations, or a representative survey.

term_definitions.name: Grazing Capacity
term_definitions.description: Grazing capacity of the area where the livestock will be displaced to.

term_definitions.name: Other Emissions
term_definitions.description: Emissions that result from certain land preparation techniques, from the use of fertilisers and energy during project activities, and from nitrogen-fixing trees are categorized as 'Other Emissions'.

term_definitions.name: The Baseline
term_definitions.description: The Baseline is the estimated carbon stock that would occur in the baseline scenario. The baseline scenario describes the activities that would occur in the absence of the proposed project.

term_definitions.name: Conversion Procedure
term_definitions.description: How to convert from the unit of cubic meters [m3] or tonnes of dry matter [tdm] to tonnes of carbon [tC] and then to tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent [tCO2].

term_definitions.name: Wood Density
term_definitions.description: The woody density is the ratio between the mass of dry wood divided by its volume. Example: Wood density = Mass / Volume = 0.6 t / 1 m3 = 0.6 t / m3. Often the unit t (tonnes) is expressed as tdm (tonnes of dry matter).

term_definitions.name: Biomass Expansion Factor (BEF)
term_definitions.description: Aboveground tree biomass / Stem biomass. Example: BEF = Aboveground tree biomass / Stem biomass = 1.3 m3/ 1 m3 = 1.3. Some BEFs already include the Root-to-Shoot ratio.

term_definitions.name: Root to Shoot Ratio
term_definitions.description: Belowground tree biomass / Aboveground tree biomass. Root-to-Shoot ratio = Belowground tree biomass / Aboveground tree biomass = 0.3 m3/ 1.3 m3 = 0.23. Most Root-to-Shoot ratios are calculated from the Tree volume (including branches and leaves/needles), but some are based on the Stem volume.

term_definitions.name: Stem Volume
term_definitions.description: Based on a specific diameter of stump (x cm). The BEF should relate to this.

term_definitions.name: Ex ante
term_definitions.description: Ex ante means 'before the event'. In the context of carbon projects, ex ante refers to the period before the project starts.

actions.description: This methodology comes into force on its publication date. The previous version of the methodology is valid until the attached date. The projects already submitted for listing or achieved listed status may continue with the previous version of methodology as long as the project is in compliance with applicable requirements of Emissions Reduction and Sequestration Product Requirements.

Identify the modelling units.
Complete forest inventories for each modelling unit.
The number of sample plots of a forest inventory is sufficient to meet a MU precision with a maximum error of ±20% at a 90% confidence interval.
supporting_info: Where the error is above 20%, the additional difference shall be deducted. For example. A forest inventory determined the mean 'Stem volume' of a MU at 100 m3/ha with an error of 23%. The error is 3% higher than required: 3% * 100 m3/ha = 3 m3/ha. The mean 'Stem volume' which can be accounted for is: 100 - 3 = 97 m3/ha.

supporting_info: Projects complying with this methodology's requirements may use the Yardstick integration Tool in order to account for SOC. The tool assists you in measuring the change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the planting of forests and applies to soils on planting areas only. Once a project has undergone a successful design certification, credits calculated using this tool may be issued following a successful performance certification. Projects shall not issue Futures resulting from this calculation tool.
